example.title: Oddtown
example.p: In a town with n people, m clubs have been formed. Every club has an odd number of members, and every two clubs have an even number of members in common. Prove that m \leq n.

Let v_i be the membership vector for club i: (v_i)_j = 1 and only if person j belongs to club i. W view these m vectors as being in the vector space \mathbb{Z}_2^n of n-tuples of integers mod 2. We will prove that the set of vectors \{v_1, v_2, \dots, v_m\} is linearly independent, which implies that m \leq n.

The conditions of problem translate to the following with respect to the dot products of these vectors. \textrm{Each club has an odd number of members }\Rightarrow v_i\cdot v_i = 1 and \textrm{Any two clubs have an even number of members in common }\Rightarrow v_i\cdot v_j = 0 \textrm{ if }i\neq j

statement.p: Let N=2^n for some positive integer n and \omega =e^{\frac{2\pi i}{N}}. Let U(\omega ) be the N\times N matrix with U(\omega)_{i,j}= \omega^{(i-1)(j-1)}. Compute U(\omega )U\left(\omega ^{-1}\right).
Let A and B be n\times n matrices satisfying A+B = A B. Show that A B = B A.
Let A be a square matrix, A \neq I, and suppose there exists a positive integer m such that A^m=I. Calculate det(I + A + A^2 + \cdots + A^{m-1}).

hint.p: The matrix that you want the determinant of is a finite geometric series.

solution.p: In general, we have (I + A + A^2 + \cdots + A^{m-1})(I -A)=(I-A^m). But the right side is the zero matrix and so for every nonzero vector x, (I + A + A^2 + \cdots + A^{m-1})(I -A)\vec{x}=\vec{0}. Since I-A \neq \vec{O}, there exist nonzero vectors \vec{x} and \vec{y} such that (I-A)\vec{x} = \vec{y}. This gives us (I + A + A^2 + \cdots + A^{m-1})\vec{y}=\vec{0} which implies that I + A + A^2 + \cdots + A^{m-1} is singular and so its determinant is zero.
This problem was from the 2006 MAA Northeast Section Math Competition.

statement.p: Let's call a real 3 \times 3 matrix a magic square if all its row-sums and column-sums are equal to 0. Show that all magic squares form a vector space. Find its dimension.

Let n be a positive integer, and let v_1, v_2, \ldots ,v_k, 1\leq k\leq n, be linearly independent vectors in \mathbb{R}^n spanning a subspace V_k. Prove that there exist k orthogonal vectors w_1, w_2, \ldots ,w_k that span V_k. (Note: Two nonzero vectors are orthogonal if their dot product is equal to 0.)

hint.p: Use the linearly of the dot product: x.(a y+z) = a(x.y)+x.z, where a is a scalar.

statement.p: Let A be the n\times n matrix whose entry in the i-th row and j-th column is \frac{1}{\min (i,j)} for 1 \leq i,j \leq n. Compute \det (A).

hint.p: Expand the determinant along the last row of the matrix.

solution.p: Let A_n be the n by n version of the matrix. Assume n \geq 3. Expand the determinant of A_n along the last row. If 1 \leq k \leq n-1 then the minor M_{n k} is the determinant of a matrix with two identical columns, which is zero. This leaves two nonzero term in the expansion. In both of the terms, the minor is the determinant of A_{n-1}. Therefore, det(A_{n}) = - a_{n,n-1} det(A_{n-1}) + a_{n,n-1} det(A_{n-1}) =\frac{-1}{(n-1)n} \cdot det(A_{n-1}).
Combining this recursion with the initial values of det(A_{1})=1 and det(A_{2})=-frac{1}{2}, we see that det(A_{n}) = \frac{(-1)^n}{n! (n-1)!}

statement.p: The dashboard of a nuclear power station has several lights. Some lights are on and some are off. There are also several buttons. Pressing each button changes the state of several lights (from on to off and from off to on). It is known that for every set of lights there exists a button connected to an odd number of lights in this set. Show that one can turn off all lights by pressing some buttons.

hint.p: Start by creating a matrix, one row for each button and a column for each light.

solution.p: Assume there are n buttons and m lights. Let A be the n \times m matrix such that A_{i j} = 1 if and only if button i is connected to light j. Let \Delta be a set of lights. We represent this set by an m dimensional column vector \delta such that \delta_{i} = 1 if and only if light i is in \Delta.

statement.p: Compute the determinant of the n \times n matrix \left[a_{i j}\right] such that a_{i j} =\lvert i-j\rvert.

Think of a square matrix as placed on a checkerboard, so that the leading diagonal consists entirely of white squares. Then if the signs of all the entries on black squares are changed, prove that the eigenvalues are unchanged.

solution.p: Let M be the diagonal matrix with M_{i i}=(-1)^i. Then if A is the given square matrix, M A M is the matrix that has the black entries of A negated.

statement.p: It is well known that all real-valued functions on \mathbb{R} form a vector space. Does the function \sin x belong to the linear span of the functions 1, \cos x, \cos 2 x, \cos 3 x,\ldots? How about the function \sin^2 x?

solution.p: Suppose \sin x = \sum_{k=1}^m \lambda_k \cos{k x}. Then we should have \int_{-\pi }^{\pi } \sin^2(x) \, dx = \int_{-\pi }^{\pi } \sin(x)(\sum_{k=1}^m \lambda_k \cos{k x} ) \, dx
